name: Calculus I
description: A detailed study of limits, continuity, derivatives of algebraic and transcendental functions, applications of derivatives, numerical techniques, integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
review: You will work with story problems and basic applications of calculus, make sure you know trigonometry and college algebra. Integration and Differentiation are fundamental concepts that you will learn in this course. - Math Professor Eddie Cheng

name: Calculus II
description: A detailed study of methods of integration, applications of the integrals, improper integrals, sequences, series and power series, polar coordinates and parametric curves.
review: I struggled with memorizing all the Integration techniques, there were a lot of them. This class focuses heavily on this. I recommend getting ahead of this class, Memorizing everything helps when you practice problems. Practice problems outside of HW and lecture and practice every technique, you are looking for certain identifiers in the question that will help you pick which technique to use and practicing helps reinforce that memory of which is which - Austin W

name: Linear Algebra
description: Formal models of computation, ranging from finite state automata to Turing machines. Computational models are used to discuss the languages recognized by these machines and address issues of computability.
review: Deals with computations, you will need to formalize an idea to solve a system using elimination. has a theoretical aspects like discrete but is not as challenging as discrete. Class has a similar difficulty level to Calc 2, my advice is to pay attention to the recap in the beginning of the course, it builds on basic concepts but it is important. - Math Professor Eddie Cheng

name: Discrete Mathematics
description: Concepts and methods of discrete mathematics with an emphasis on their application to computer science. Logic and proofs, sets and relations, algorithms, induction and recursion, combinatorics, graphs and trees.
review: This is the hardest math course needed for the degree in our opinion. there is no specific algorithm or direct direction towards an answer for problems in discrete and students struggle with this. My advice is to stick with it and practice often. It can be easy to follow along in class but it is another thing to answer questions on your own from scratch. Our advice is to stick with it and form a study group. - Math Professor Eddie Cheng and Austin W

name: Applied Probability and Statistics
description: Introduction to probability and statistics as applied to the physical, biological and social sciences and to engineering. Applications of special distributions and nonparametric techniques. Regression analysis and analysis of variance.
review: Statistics is a challenging course that mixes probability concepts with real-world statistics, requiring both math skills and practice. Focus on understanding the basics and working through problems consistently to do well.

name: Introduction to C Programming and Unix
description: Topics include binary numbers and C programming concepts such as data types, bitwise operations, control flow, arrays, pointers, structures, and input/output. Basic Unix commands and shell programming are covered, as well as Unix utilities for developing and debugging C programs.
review: Not too difficult of a class, with simple assignments to learn coding in not just the language, but also fundamental concepts for all coding languages, as well as a group course project. This project will require solid knowledge on all topics, just make sure to not procrastinate on this or any other assignments. - Nicholas Sakowski

name: Object-Oriented Computing
description: Introduction to object-oriented computer programming using a high-level programming language such as Java. Classes, member functions, inheritance, polymorphism and operator overloading. Design methodologies and introduction to software engineering principles and practices. Basic data structures, algorithms and event driven programming concepts are introduced.
review: This course effectively serves as a more in-depth introduction to coding in Java, specifically with the use of object-based programming. Weekly assignments, as well as a final project, are given to test your knowledge periodically. Be sure to not fall behind on understanding topics. - Nicholas Sakowski

name: Data Structures
description: This course covers data structures using object oriented programming. The fundamental data structures in computer science, including stacks, queues, lists and trees are covered in detail. Concepts of design, analysis and verification are discussed in the context of abstract data types.
review: This course builds on your knowledge of programming in Java, teaching you how to declare functionality in a file for various types of data storage, as well as call it in a runnable file to perform operations on this data structure. Occasional projects are assigned requiring you to implement specific code to perform operations on a data structure to receive a desired output. Lectures aid in learning how these structures work and provide you with similar code, so make sure to attend especially these lectures. - Nicholas Sakowski

name: Introduction to Computer Networks
review: Networking is mostly a matter of getting the work done and not procrastinating, stay on top of the class and you should be fine. The classwork is pretty straight forward so my advice is honestly just to get yourself to sit down and do the homework and labs. Assignments in this class take some time and you should prepare for that. - Brandon R

name: Sophomore Project
description: A team-oriented project work consisting of a small project to build skills in needs assessment, group problem solving, and written and oral technical presentations.
review: The project that you pick should be something you are proud enough to throw on a resume. I recommend getting a massive head start because the closer you get to the end of the semester, the harder your other classes get. This is not something to procrastinate.

name: Software Engineering and Practice
description: Introduction to software engineering and practice. Topics include software process models, project and software management, requirements analysis, architecture modeling, implementation and system integration, quality assurance, and testing.
review: Covers software development methodologies, teamwork, and project management. Stay organized and actively participate in group work for the best results.

name: Theory of Computation
description: Formal models of computation, ranging from finite state automata to Turing machines. Computational models are used to discuss the languages recognized by these machines and address issues of computability.
review: Explores computational theory, including automata, Turing machines, and complexity classes. Be prepared for abstract thinking and lots of problem-solving.

name: Database Design and Implementation
description: Introduction to the design, implementation and management of database systems. Topics include planning, designing, and implementing a practical database using a relational database server for an application utilizing entity relationship diagrams, normal forms, and understanding relational database schemas. Advanced topics include concurrency control, query optimization, and introduction to database systems administration.
review: Focuses on database models, SQL, and implementation techniques. Hands-on practice with queries and design is key to mastering the course.

name: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
description: Computer algorithms, their design and analysis. Strategies constructing algorithmic solutions, including divide-and-conquer, dynamic programming and greedy algorithms. Computational complexity as it pertains to time and space is used to evaluate the algorithms.
review: This class involves integration of math concepts for algorithm design. It is recommended to take and understand the concepts from Data Structures before taking this course, as well as have a solid understanding of math concepts up to this point. - Nicholas Sakowski

name: Security and Privacy in Computing
description: An introduction to principles and practices of security and privacy. Topics include an introduction to cryptography, host/network exploits and countermeasures, information risk assessment, access control, threat and incident management, information privacy concepts, privacy requirements, privacy-enhancing technologies, information privacy management, and legal and regulatory requirements. With laboratory.
review: Introduces cybersecurity principles, including encryption, authentication, and threat analysis. Pay attention to details and practice secure coding techniques.

name: Computer Organization
description: Introduction to digital logic. Assembly language, addressing modes, RISC and CISC architectures, assemblers, loaders, linkers, arithmetic and logic unit, hardware functional units, input/output organization, memory organization, cache memory, virtual memory, control unit.
review: Explains how computers work at the hardware and assembly language level. Focus on understanding system architecture and low-level programming.

name: Programming Languages
description: Fundamental concepts in programming languages. Several high-level languages are studied in depth and their approaches to the fundamental issues in language design are compared. Issues include: scanning and parsing, type checking and type inference, control structures, operational semantics, binding times, run-time storage organization, compilation vs interpretation, block structure and scope of names. Formerly CSI 3350. Credit can not be earned for both CSI 3350 and CSI 4350.
review: Explores language paradigms (e.g., functional, logic, imperative) and design principles. Be ready to work with unfamiliar programming languages.

name: Information Security Practice
description: Introduction to both theoretical and hands-on aspects of vulnerability assessment, penetration testing, and system hardening. Topics include basics of confidentiality, integrity and authentication; footprinting, scanning, assessment and validations of systems and application vulnerabilities; system remediation, implementation of security policies using host and network level firewalls and intrusion detection and prevention system.
review: Emphasizes applied techniques for securing systems and networks. Regular practice with security tools is key.

name: Network Security
description: Network Security will provide students a good understanding of different security aspects related to computer networks. Methods of network attacks and ways to defend against them will be discussed. Topics include attacks to different layers, security technologies, link layer security, network layer security, transport layer security and application layer security. Cross-listed with CSI 5600.
review: Covers securing network infrastructures and protocols. Prioritize understanding encryption and firewall techniques.

name: Advanced Web Design Application
description: Advanced concepts in web design including protocols for integrating databases and effective information exchange necessary for developing enterprise resource management systems are covered. Evolving technologies and web application development architectures, including multi- tier processing, session management, security, and availability are discussed. The students complete a web application as a part of the course. Crosslisted with CSI 5510.
review: Covers advanced topics in web development, including performance and scalability. Focus on optimizing code and deployment practices.

name: AI for IT Operations
description: This course introduces participants to MLOps tools and best practices for deploying, evaluating, monitoring and operating production ML systems on the Cloud. MLOps is a discipline focused on the deployment, testing, monitoring, and automation of ML systems in production. Cross-listed with CSI 5150.
review: Teaches AI techniques for optimizing IT systems and workflows. Understanding cloud infrastructure and AI concepts is vital.

name: Fundamentals of Operating Systems
description: Introduction to the concepts and design of operating systems. Typical topics include: sequential processes, concurrent processes, processor management, memory management, scheduling, file management, and resource protection.
review: Covers OS principles like process management, memory allocation, and file systems. Understanding how systems work under the hood is critical.

name: Parallel and Distributed Computing
description: This course provides an integrated view of the architecture, principles, and programming of parallel and distributed systems. Topics include instruction-level parallelism and its limitations, classification of parallel systems, shared-memory and distributed-memory architectures, distributed storage systems, foundation of parallel algorithms, distributed systems architecture, and programming interfaces for parallel and distributed computing.
review: Focuses on parallelism, distributed systems, and concurrent programming. Be prepared for complex coding challenges and conceptual depth.

name: Senior Capstone Project
description: A team-oriented senior project to synthesize the knowledge and skills gained in the CS/IT curricula. Written and oral reports are required in addition to a working demo.
review: A culminating course where students design and complete a significant project. Plan your time well and collaborate effectively with your team.

name: Genetics
description: Fundamentals of classical and molecular genetics. Selected topics in human genetics, microbial genetics, biochemical genetics, molecular biology, cytogenetics and genomics.
prerequisites: BIO 1200 with a grade of (C) or higher
review: Covers the principles of heredity, molecular genetics, and gene regulation. Regularly review diagrams and problem sets for comprehension.

name: Bioinformatics
description: This course covers the fundamental algorithms and computational methods for study of biological sequence data for comparative biology and evolution with the focus on discovery of genome content, function and organization. Specific methodologies covered include the algorithms for searching sequence databases, pair-wise and multiple sequence alignment, phylogenetic methods, and methods for pattern recognition and functional inference from sequence data.
review: Applies computational methods to biological data, such as genome analysis. Balance coding practice with understanding biological concepts.

name: Information Security
description: Introduction to cryptography and its application to networking and operating system security. Topics covered include secret key and public key cryptographic algorithms, hash functions, authentication, digital signature, digital certificate, key management, email security, web security, SSL/TLS, IP security and wireless security, firewalls, intrusion detection and traceback techniques, security threats and countermeasures, and legal and ethical issues. Independent research on network security is required as student projects.
review: Explores foundational security principles, including risk management and cryptography. Focus on case studies and practical application.

name: Software Security
description: Introduction to research in foundations of software security. This course surveys common software vulnerabilities, including buffer overflows, format string attacks, cross-site scripting and botnets. The course also discusses common defense mechanisms, including static code analysis, reference monitors, language-based security, secure information flow and others.
review: Teaches secure coding practices and techniques for identifying vulnerabilities. Consistent practice with real-world scenarios is essential.

name: Mathematics of Cryptology
description: Classic cryptosystems (Hill, Vigene’re, one-time-pad), divisibility, modular arithmetic and efficient operations on large integers; practical cryptosystems (AES, RSA, DES), algebra of prime fields, prime factorization, discrete log problem, complexity theory, hash functions, birthday attacks. Modern and future cryptosystems, zero-knowledge proofs, quantum key exchange.
prerequisites: CSI 3610 with grade of (C) or higher
review: Explores the mathematical principles behind cryptography. Be ready for a heavy emphasis on number theory and algorithms.

name: Computational Intelligence
description: This course provides an introduction to the fundamental techniques of artificial intelligence for problem solving and inference. Topics include uninformed and informed search, adversarial search, reasoning under uncertainty, knowledge representation, planning, and machine learning models. Individual or group projects on current applications in AI.
review: Covers AI fundamentals like search algorithms, logic, and knowledge representation. Focus on understanding core concepts and applying them in coding projects.

name: Information Retrieval and Knowledge Discovery
description: This course covers the models for information retrieval from text and multimedia databases. Methodologies for database indexing and visualization are discussed. Statistical and deterministic algorithms for discovering knowledge from databases, including, decision trees, clustering, regression, and neural models are covered.
review: Covers data mining, search engines, and retrieval systems. Pay attention to algorithms and practical applications in handling large datasets.

name: Engineering Operations Research
description: Introduction to operations research models used in decision making and system performance evaluation. Topics include linear programming including simplex method and duality theory, integer linear programming, the assignment and transportation problems, network flows and dynamic programming. Cross-listed with ISE 3330.
prerequisites: MTH 1555 with a grade of (C) or higher and a 2000 level APM/MTH class
review: Covers optimization techniques for engineering problems, including linear programming and decision-making models. Focus on understanding algorithms and applications.

name: Systems Administration
description: This course teaches the skills necessary to analyze, deploy, manage and troubleshoot Linux servers. Topics include user authentication management, system configuration and management, periodic tasks automation, data backup techniques, server deployments, system maintenance and performance analysis, and security aspects of Linux systems.
review: Teaches foundational skills for managing and maintaining computer systems. Hands-on experience with operating systems and networks is essential.

name: Advanced Systems Administration
description: Advanced concepts in enterprise computing infrastructure analysis, deployment, management and troubleshooting. Topics include enterprise computing resource requirements analysis and design, single sign-on management, application and server deployment, virtualization, security configurations, and performance analysis.
review: Focuses on managing large-scale systems in enterprise environments. Stay organized and focus on troubleshooting skills.

name: Game Design
description: This course teaches modern methods for designing and assessing the design of digital games. The course distinguishes game design from game development. Students learn theory, concepts, and industry best-practices for designing and critically analyzing games. Students apply this understanding to iteratively design their own games with popular game prototyping software.
review: Covers game mechanics, storytelling, and player engagement. Creativity and attention to detail are essential for success.

name: Game Programming
description: The course teaches game development skills that can be applied in various industries. Students learn to utilize various assets, game objects, and components to create diverse genres of 2D and 3D games in the Unity game engine using C# or other similar tools. Additionally, students collaborate in teams to produce fully functional games.
prerequisites: CSI 1300, CSI 1320, CSI 1420 or EGR 1400 & Major Standing
review: Focuses on programming concepts for building games, including graphics and physics. Hands-on coding projects are critical for mastering the material.

name: Mobile Security
description: This course provides a general overview of the security and privacy aspects of mobile computing. Topics include, mobile vulnerabilities, mobile malware, smartphone security, secure mobile app development, data privacy, biometrics-, multi-factor-, and codependency-based authentication and vulnerabilities, mobile location privacy, authentication in mobile devices, and secure apps communication.
review: Focuses on securing mobile platforms and applications. Stay current with evolving threats and best practices.

name: C++ for Programmers
description: A course in C++ programming for programmers with basic knowledge of data types and control structures in programming languages. Topics include pointers, memory management, classes, polymorphism, overloading, templates, input/output, parameter passing, multiple inheritance, standard template library, and philosophical differences in major object-oriented programming languages.
prerequisites: EGR 1400 or CSI 1300 or CSI 1320 or CSI 1420 or CSI 2300
review: A short course focusing on C++ basics for programmers with prior experience. Practice syntax and concepts like pointers and classes.

name: Immersive Python
description: This course introduces the fundamentals and applications of Python. The language fundamentals covered are statements, variables, comments, control structures, functions, modules, packages, and objects. The course also includes advanced concepts such as collections (Lists, Tuples and Dictionaries) with their practical use for Data Processing, Systems administration, and Web development applications. Students can receive credit for CSI 1320 or CSI 2330, but not both.
prerequisites: EGR 1400  or CSI 1300 or CSI 1420 or CSI 2300
review: Provides a quick and practical dive into Python programming. Great for beginners; focus on writing clean, readable code.

name: Ruby for Web Developers
description: This course introduces the dynamic programming language Ruby – focusing on language fundamentals, debugging and external language binding techniques, and extremely popular web development framework Ruby on the Rail (ROR). The basic ROR topics include discussion of convention over configuration as used by ROR and RESTful web development with practical exercises.
prerequisites: EGR 1400 or CSI 1300 or CSI 1320 or CSI 1420 or CSI 2300
review: Covers Ruby fundamentals with a focus on web development frameworks like Rails. Practice coding small projects to reinforce learning. Stay on top of the homework and you will be okay. - Austin W

name: Programming in Visual C# for .NET Technology
description: This course covers C#.NET for programmers who already have the basic knowledge for object-oriented programming techniques. Topics include: Windows forms, Common Language Run Time (CLR), assemblies, ADO.NET, XML, Web Services, Mobile and Embedded Development.
review: Introduces C# and .NET development for building robust applications. Stay consistent with hands-on coding to grasp the framework.

name: Big Data Analysis with Cloud Computing
description: Topics related to storage, management, and analysis of Big Data on cloud platform by introducing technologies like Hadoop with MapReduce, Spark, Pig, and Hive. It also covers modeling and implementation of Big Data using various NoSQL databases such as Key-value, Columnar, Document, and graph-based. It includes a semester-long team project.
review: Focuses on analyzing large datasets using cloud platforms. Strong programming and analytical skills are essential.

name: Introduction to Data Science in Python
description: An introductory level overview of data science lifecycle topics including data acquisition, management, preparation, analysis, model development and deployment, and data visualization.Students will gain practical experience by learning and applying libraries and packages that comprise Python data analysis ecosystem. It emphasizes concepts and strategies for writing Python code. With Laboratory.
review: Teaches Python programming for data manipulation, analysis, and visualization. Focus on using libraries like pandas and matplotlib.

name: Mobile Application Development
description: This course focuses on mobile application development using underlying frameworks, architecture, design, and implementation. Both classroom theory and hands-on labs enable students to gain in-depth experience in developing real-world mobile applications. Topics include mobile user interface development, mobile application framework components, sensors integration, networking and persistent storage.
review: Focuses on developing apps for mobile platforms. Practical coding experience and understanding of UI/UX are crucial.

name: Software Verification and Testing
description: This course is designed to introduce the basic principles and techniques, facilitated by state-of-the-art software tools, in software verification and testing. Real-world examples are adopted to help understand and practice the underlying theory. Cross-listed with CSI 5370.
review: Explores techniques for ensuring software reliability and quality. Practice debugging and testing methodologies frequently.

name: Cloud Computing
description: The course explores latest advances in hardware and software, system architecture, and new programming paradigms that are used to develop high-throughput distributed computer systems. Topics covered include computer clusters, virtual machines, automated data centers, cloud platform architectures, service-oriented architectures, cloud programming and software environments, grid computing, and peer-to-peer computing. The course will be supplemented by selected topics from recent technical literature. Cross-listed with CSI 5240.
review: Focuses on building and managing applications in cloud environments. Hands-on work with cloud platforms is essential.

name: Contemporary Issues in Data Science
description: The course provides an introduction to the relationship between data, ethics, governance, policy, and society to help students think explicitly about their social responsibilities as data scientists using case studies and examples. The course emphasizes writing and critical thinking.
prerequisites: WRT 1060 with a grade of C or higher & Major Standing
review: Explores current trends and ethical considerations in data science. Engage with real-world case studies and discussions.

name: Data Visualization
description: The course introduces interactive data visualization. Students learn best practices in data visualization and how to design and implement dashboards for use by stakeholders. It provides hands-on experiences using popular visualization software such as Tableau. Students practice data visualization skills in multiple assignments and a comprehensive semester-long team project. With Laboratory.
review: Covers techniques for visualizing complex datasets effectively. Focus on both design principles and technical implementation.

name: Web and Mobile Systems
description: An introduction to web and mobile systems. Development of interactive web systems using front-end technologies such as HTML, CSS and JavaScript during the first half of the semester. A cross platform JavaScript framework, such as React Native along with React Library, for mobile apps development during the second half.
review: Covers foundational concepts in web and mobile app development. Focus on building functional and responsive designs.

name: Integrated Computing Systems
description: The course integrates various system components such as databases, web servers, user APIs, and cloud technologies and services. Topics include integration of various devices with web servers and cloud services. Students will gain hands-on experience in developing and integrating each of these system components with exposure to appropriate hardware, software, and simulation platforms.
review: Focuses on building complex, integrated systems for the web. Regular practice with full-stack development tools is recommended.

name: Intro to Python and Unix
description: Algorithmic programming using Python. Topics include data storage and manipulation, binary numbers, bitwise operations, control structures, and functions. Introduction to fundamental data structures and script programming. Basic Unix commands and Unix utilities will be covered.
review: Intro to Python is relatively easy, if this is your first coding class I would bump the rating to a 2 star, it will be difficult but understand every language follows the same core concepts so while it will feel like learning a new language like Spanish, the other coding languages will be easier to follow. - Austin W

name: Writing Foundations
description: Methods of writing and research including the use of rhetorical strategies and synthesis of scholarly sources to create academic arguments. Emphasizes processes of writing and revision with a focus on information literacy, critical thinking, and effective communication in diverse rhetorical contexts.
review: Covers the basics of academic writing, including essays, grammar, and structure. Focus on feedback and revising your work to improve.

name: Biology I
description: Introduction to cellular and molecular biology, enzymology, metabolism, genetics, cell division. One year of high school chemistry is strongly recommended. Satisfies the university general education requirement in the natural science and technology knowledge exploration area.
review: An introduction to biology, covering topics like cells, genetics, and ecology. Keep up with readings and lectures for a solid understanding.

name: Biology Laboratory
description: Laboratory and field experience emphasizing scientific method, scientific writing, Mendelian genetics, vertebrate anatomy and animal and plant diversity. Offered fall and winter semester.
review: Hands-on experiments that complement Biology I, emphasizing lab techniques and analysis. Pay attention to details and follow instructions closely.

name: Biology II
description: Introduction to evolution, biological diversity, and ecology. Covers (1) micro- and macroevolution including the origin and history of life; (2) biological diversity of microorganism, fungus, plant, and animal phyla including taxonomy, structure, and function; and (3) behavior, ecology, and conservation biology. Satisfies the university general education requirement in the natural science and technology knowledge exploration area.
prerequisites: BIO 1200 recommended & Satisfies the university general education requirement in the natural science and technology knowledge exploration area.
review: A continuation of Biology I, focusing on more advanced topics like evolution, physiology, and ecosystems. Review notes often and stay organized.

name: General Chemistry I
description: States of matter, atomic structure, bonding and molecular structure, chemical reactions. Recommended preparation is three years high school mathematics and one year of high school chemistry. General Education Requirement(s): CHM 1440 and CHM 1470 together satisfy the university general education requirement in the natural science and technology knowledge exploration area.
review: Covers core chemistry principles like atomic structure, bonding, and stoichiometry. Practice problem-solving regularly to grasp the concepts.

name: General Chemistry Laboratory I
description: Experimental investigation of chemical phenomena and measurements.  Accompanies CHM 1440 but does not have to be taken concurrently.  May be taken with permission by students who have completed CHM 1430.
review: Hands-on experiments to apply concepts from General Chemistry I. Precision and preparation are essential for success.

name: Introductory Physics I
description: Classical mechanics and thermodynamics. For science, mathematics and engineering students.
review: An algebra-based physics course covering motion, forces, and energy. Focus on understanding the formulas and practicing problems.

name: General Physics Lab I
description: Elementary experiments in mechanics, thermodynamics and waves.
review: Complements Introductory Physics I with experiments on mechanics and energy. Attention to detail and good teamwork will help.

name: Introduction to Ethics in Science and Engineering
description: Survey of canonical works in the history of Western ethical theory providing students a critical understanding of a plurality of viable ideas, principles, and criteria by which to evaluate and judge contemporary issues of ethical concern in the practice of science and engineering.
review: the class revolves around moral considerations in engineering. It is a relatively easy class as long as you show up. You will have to write case studies and students can struggle with that. - Professor Elysa White

name: Deep Learning and Applications
description: Introduction to learning, background knowledge for computer vision and natural language processing, linear models for regression and classification, perceptron learning, backpropagation and shallow neural networks, deep learning basics and software frameworks, convolutional neural networks, applications in object detection and semantic segmentation, autoencoders, visualization of learned convolution masks, recurrent neural networks, applications to sequences, generative adversarial networks, reinforcement learning.
review: Explores neural networks and deep learning frameworks with real-world applications. Be prepared for intensive programming and a strong math focus.

name: Machine Learning
description: Introduction to recognition and learning; Bayes decision theory; parametric and nonparametric methods including Hidden Markov models; Discriminant functions including support vector machines; Multilayer neural networks; Decision and regression trees for learning; Performance estimation; Unsupervised learning and clustering; Subspace methods; Application.
review: Covers supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning algorithms. Pay close attention to mathematical foundations and practice implementing models.

name: Natural Language Processing
description: This course introduces the linguistic, mathematical, and computational fundamentals of natural language processing: the creation of computer programs that model human languages (e.g., English), enabling applications like automatic text categorization, machine translation, and chatbots. Topics include text preprocessing, language modeling, classification, tagging, parsing, semantics, discourse and dialog analysis, text generation, and the use of modern NLP toolkits. Non-CS majors should have some programming background.
review: Focuses on language modeling, parsing, and text processing. Stay on top of theory and practice coding to apply concepts effectively.

name: Visual Computing
description: This course is a comprehensive introduction to image processing and computer vision in the spatial domain. Topics include digital image fundamentals, intensity transformations, spatial filtering, morphological image processing, and image registration and image segmentation.
review: Explores computer vision and graphics concepts like image processing and 3D rendering. Hands-on projects are key to understanding the material.

name: Introduction to Differential Equations with Matrix Algebra
description: Introduction to ordinary differential equations, Laplace transforms, linear systems, matrices, vectors, independence, Eigenvalues and eigenvectors, and applications. Students cannot receive credit for both APM 2555 and APM 2559.
prerequisites: MTH 1555 with a grade of (C) or higher
review: Explores differential equations and matrix algebra fundamentals. Regular practice with solving equations is crucial.

name: Applied Matrix Theory
description: Eigenvalues, eigenvectors and their applications, matrix calculus, linear differential equations, Jordan canonical forms, and quadratic forms. Time will also be spent on various computational techniques.
prerequisites: MTH 2775 with grade of (C) or higher
review: Focuses on advanced linear algebra applications in science and engineering. Be ready for computational and theoretical challenges.

name: Numerical Methods
description: Approximations and interpolations, propagation of errors, numerical differentiation and integration, solutions of equations, Newton’s method, solutions of differential equations and initial value problems, Runge-Kutta and predictor-corrector methods. Required background includes courses in linear algebra and differential equations. APM 5333 is cross-listed with an undergraduate course, APM 4333. Student may not receive credit for both courses.
prerequisites: MTH 2775 with a grade of (C) or higher, (APM 2555 with a grade of (C) or higher or APM 2559 with a grade of (C) or higher), and knowledge of a scientific programming language, or permission of the instructor
review: Teaches numerical techniques for solving scientific and engineering problems. A balance of programming and mathematical understanding is required.

name: Applied Numerical Methods: Matrix Methods
description: Systems of linear equations, Gaussian elimination, LU factorization, successive over-relaxation, approximation theory, curve fitting, eigenvalue problems, iterative techniques and non-linear systems of equations, some aspects of boundary value problems and introduction to numerical solutions of partial differential equations.  Required background includes courses in multi-variable calculus and linear algebra and knowledge of a scientific programming language. Cross-listed with APM 5334. Student may not receive credit for both courses.
prerequisites: MTH 2554 with a grade of (C) or higher, MTH 2775 with a grade of (C) or higher and knowledge of a scientific programming language, or permission of the instructor
review: Covers numerical matrix methods for computational problems. Strong focus on applications and computational tools.

name: Applied Mathematics: Discrete Methods I
description: Elementary graph theory (trees, cycles, planar graphs and flows) and elementary enumeration (generating function, 0-1 strings, planted plane trees, cycle decomposition and Lagrange’s inversion formula). Required background includes courses in linear algebra and discrete methods. APM 5663 is cross-listed with an undergraduate course, APM 4663. Student may not receive credit for both courses.
review: Explores discrete math topics such as graph theory and combinatorics. Focus on logical reasoning and proofs.

name: Computer Algebra
description: A study of the mathematics and algorithms which are used in symbolic algebraic manipulation packages. Topics include computer representation of symbolic mathematics, polynomial ring theory, field theory and algebraic extensions, modular and p-adic methods, subresultant algorithm for polynomial GCD’s, Groebner bases for polynomial ideals and Buchberger’s algorithm, factorization and zeros of polynomials. Required background includes a course in abstract algebra and knowledge of a scientific programming language. Cross-listed with APM 5777. Student may not receive credit for both courses.
prerequisites: MTH 2775 with a grade of (C) or higher and knowledge of a scientific computer programming language, or permission of instructor
review: Covers symbolic computation and algebraic algorithms. Be prepared for a mix of programming and advanced math.

name: Introduction to Electrical and Computer Engineering
description: An introduction to the fundamentals of electrical and computer engineering, DC and AC circuits, digital logic circuits, combinational logic design, sequential circuits, introduction to electronics, operational amplifiers and DC electromechanical machines. With laboratory. Offered fall and winter.
review: Introduces electrical engineering concepts with practical applications. A hands-on approach to circuits and basic systems is essential.

name: Complex Variables
description: A study of analytic functions of a complex variable including differentiation and integration, series representations, the theory of residues and applications.
prerequisites: MTH 2554 with a grade of (C) or higher
review: Explores the theory of complex numbers and functions. Strong focus on mathematical proofs and applications.

name: General Physics Lab II
description: Elementary experiments in electricity and magnetism, optics and modern physics.
review: Complements physics coursework with hands-on experiments. Precision and good lab documentation are key.

name: Biological Physics
description: Applications of physics to biology, including biomechanics, fluid dynamics, statistical mechanics, diffusion, bioelectricity, biomagnetism, feedback and control.
prerequisites: PHY 1020 or PHY 1520 and MTH 1555 recommended
review: Covers physics concepts applied to biological systems. Interdisciplinary approach requires understanding both physics and biology fundamentals.

name: Medical Physics
description: Applications of physics to medicine, including signal analysis, imaging, x-rays, nuclear medicine and magnetic resonance imaging.
prerequisites: PHY 1020 or PHY 1520 and MTH 1555 recommended
review: Explores physics applications in medicine, including imaging and radiation. Strong focus on applied problem-solving and concepts.

name: Optics
description: Geometrical optics, optical instruments, wave theory of reflection, refraction, interference, diffraction and polarization of light.
prerequisites: recommended PHY 1020 or PHY 1520 and MTH 1555
review: Covers principles of light, reflection, refraction, and wave optics. Pay attention to mathematical derivations and lab experiments.

name: Vibrations and Waves
description: Oscillations; mechanical waves in one, two and three dimensions; sound.
review: Focuses on oscillations and wave phenomena in various physical systems. Strong mathematical skills are needed for understanding models.

name: Foundations of Modern Physics
description: Introduction to relativity, kinetic theory, quantization and atomic physics. Additional topics chosen from physics of molecules, solids, nuclei and elementary particles.
review: Introduces concepts like relativity and quantum mechanics. A solid grasp of calculus and physics basics is crucial.

name: Intermediate Algebra
description: Rational expressions; radicals and rational exponents; solving rational and radical equations, quadratic equations; introduction to functions and their graphs; exponential and logarithmic functions; applications and problem solving.
review: It may be easy for me to say this will not be too difficult, but math is different for everyone. You are at the start of that journey and my advice is to just practice outside of class and good luck! - Austin W

name: Elementary Algebra
description: Order of operations; algebra of exponents; variable expressions; linear equations and inequalities in one variable; graphing and lines; linear systems of equations in two and three variables; polynomial arithmetic; factoring; solving equations by factoring; applications and problem solving
review: You will work with the fundamentals of math, If you are worried about reaching Discrete Math from here, just take it one step at a time, when I started my math journey I was not great at it and now im in Discrete Math making it work, if I could do it so can you! Good luck! - Austin W

name: College Algebra
description: Functions, roots of polynomials, rational, exponential, and logarithmic functions.
review: Walking into this class from MTH 0662 or as your first college math class is an adjustment, that is why I rated it 3 stars. if you are new to college and Computer Science, Math classes are tricky and this class will show that. If you put in the effort and study it should not be that bad, it will take work though. - Austin W

name: Trigonometry
description: Trigonometric functions (including graphs, identities, inverse functions, equations and applications); complex numbers, analytic geometry and conic sections
review: There are some things you will have to memorize for this class and it can be challenging but splitting up college algebra and Trigonometry makes dealing with each easier. My advice is to memorize the Unit Circle, as that is something you will use in calc 2. - Austin W

name: PreCalculus
description: Functions, roots of polynomials, rational, exponential and logarithmic functions, trigonometric functions (including graphs, identities, inverse functions, equations and applications), complex numbers, analytic geometry and conic sections.
review: Definitely on the tougher side, there is a lot memorization with this class. Math was my strongest subject before I took this and I did not struggle but it was definitely challenging at times, definitely will test your algebra skills, a course you will need to study and prepare for. This is graded as a 3 star class because it is a big step for math as you walk towards Calculus, prepare yourself. - Brandon R
